question: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of progressive walking difficulty for the past year. Nine months ago he noticed weakness in his grip with thinning of his hand muscles first on the right and then on the left side. There are no sensory complaints or sphincter disturbance. On examination, there is muscle wasting with a power of 3/5 proximally and distally in both lower limbs with brisk reflexes. Asymmetric wasting is present in both his hands with intact reflexes. An oral cavity examination shows fine rippling movement in the tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis of this man's condition?

A 28-year-old man falls and rolls along the pavement for 100 m. He has multiple contusions and abrasions involving the skin of his torso and extremities, but none on his head. He is unconscious. There is no decerebrate posturing. A CT scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage or edema and no skull fractures. He remains in a persistent vegetative state. Which of the following pathological findings is most likely to be present?
A researcher wants to see the effects of pain killer medication among three groups of post-surgical patients. What best statistical test is suited in this scenario?

A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a traumatic spinal cord injury after a road traffic accident. Examination reveals spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Which of the following benzodiazepines has the longest duration of action and is most suitable in this case?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after cutting his finger with a handsaw. There is a deep 2-cm long laceration on his right index finger. Bupivacaine is used as local anesthesia for suturing. What is the most common toxic adverse effect of bupivacaine?

A 2-month-old male presents to the clinic with a history of progressively enlarging head size since birth. His fontanelles are bulging and tense. Regarding the anatomy of the ventricles which of the following is true?

answers.option: Foramen of Monroe connects the lateral and 4th ventricles
Sylvian aqueduct connects the lateral and 3rd ventricles
There are two foramen of Magendie
CSF enters subarachnoid space by foramen of Luschka

question: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with sudden urinary retention and lower limb weakness. The neurosurgeon is called, urgent surgery is recommended after relevant imaging studies. To establish a diagnosis of cauda equina syndrome, besides the aforementioned symptoms, what other clinical feature must be present?

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room after head trauma with complaints of headache and bleeding from the right ear. CT scan shows a right temporal bone fracture. He is discharged after a period of observation. One week later he came with difficulty in closing the right eye, which of the following nerve is likely to be involved in this case?

A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive bilateral asymmetric tremors, which disappear upon performing routine activities. He has no history of forgetfulness. His attendants notice his movements are slow and sluggish. There is no history of falls, difficulty in swallowing, or respiratory problems. Upon questioning, his daughter reports a long history of constipation and sleep issues such as dream reenactments and insomnia. An MRI of the brain shows insignificant age-related changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of neck pain and difficulty in carrying out daily activities. He has a previous history of falls. Neurological examination findings reveal weakness and sensory disturbance more on upper limbs than on lower limbs. What kind of spinal cord injury is most likely?

A 48-year-old male comes to the emergency room, with complaints of headache, malaise, mental confusion, and vomiting. The cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a pleocytosis made up of mononuclear and neutrophils, an elevated protein concentration, and moderately reduced or normal glucose. What microorganism commonly causes chronic bacterial meningitis?

A 39-year-old male presents to a neurologist's clinic with complaints of double vision and drooping of the upper eyelid. After examination and investigation, a diagnosis of damage to the oculomotor nucleus at the level of superior colliculus was made. What structure is not seen at this level?

A 26-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with complaints of bilateral lower limb weakness and urinary incontinence for 3 days. She has a history of painful vision loss in the left eye a year ago which resolved on its own within few days. On examination, she has spastic paraparesis with sensory loss from the toes up to the level of the umbilicus. On funduscopic examination, there is optic atrophy on the left side. An MRI is ordered and T2 imaging shows areas of hyperintensities around the lateral ventricles and a post-contrast T1 sequence reveals a large hyperintense lesion in the spinal cord at the T8 level. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A woman brings her 13-year-old son to the psychiatry department after many complaints from the school that the child does not speak properly and has trouble articulating his words. His grades have also been falling. The child's Intelligence quotient (IQ) is checked and is found to be 57. Which of the following terms best describes the intellectual disability of this child?
A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaint of inability to taste anything on the anterior portion of his tongue. What nerve innervates this part of the tongue?
A 33-year-old man undergoes surgery under general anesthesia. Which of the following anesthetic agents can sensitize the heart to the effects of catecholamines?
A 37-year-old male presents with double vision. Initial evaluation concludes he has lateral rectus palsy. Which cranial nerve is most likely lesioned in this young man?

A 62-year-old man is brought to the neurology clinic by his son with complaints of walking slower every day and tremors of hands at rest for 1 year. In the last 6 months, he has also become forgetful of recent events and asks simple questions repeatedly. Recently, he started claiming that he could see an elephant and a tiger in his room. These problems have become progressively worse gradually. He has had a couple of falls in this period but luckily did not acquire any major injury. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A researcher wants to see the differences in means among two groups of blood sugar control with new and old hypoglycemic drugs. What statistical test is best suited?
A 14-year-old adolescent suddenly begins choking while having dinner and is in severe distress. What life-saving intervention must be done immediately?

A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident with an altered level of consciousness and vomiting. GCS is motor 4, eye-opening 2, and verbal 1. Pupils are equal and reactive. CT scan reveals multiple frontoparietal contusions along with effacement of sulci and cisterns. Intracranial pressure can be reduced by which of the following management techniques?
A researcher has different types of variables in their data set. They have categorical data as well as discrete data in the study. Which test will be used to analyze nominal data?

A 78-year-old male comes to the neurology outpatient clinic with complaints of diminished facial expression, stooping posture, slowing of voluntary movement, muscle rigidity, and a “pill-rolling” tremor. He complains of taking short quick-paced steps when walking. An acute parkinsonian syndrome and destruction of neurons in the substantia nigra follows exposure to which of the following toxins?

A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever and a headache for the last 20 days. He describes the headache as gradual in onset and moderate in intensity. In the last 10 days, he suffered three episodes of generalized seizures followed by weakness on the right side of the body. He was recently treated for a middle ear infection last month. He has a history of diabetes mellitus, controlled with metformin twice daily. On examination, his GCS is 15/15, right-sided power 2/5 in the upper and lower right limb, and speech is slurred. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department with an altered mental state and two episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He also complains of low-grade fever with headaches for the past month. On examination, GCS is 13/15, with bilateral 6th nerve palsy. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 12/mm3 (N- 0-10/mm3) with predominant lymphocytes, protein 110 mg/dl (N <40 mg/dl), and glucose 40 mg/dl (N- 40-70 mg/dl). Gram and India ink staining were negative. MRI of the brain shows leptomeningeal enhancement in the base of the brain sections. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old male came to the emergency room, with complaints of malaise, headache, and fever for 3 days and now the slightest touch is painful and produces violent motor responses or even convulsions. Negri bodies are the cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites usually devoid of inflammation. Which of the following virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods?

A 39-year-old female is scheduled to undergo a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The anesthesiology team decides to perform induction with propofol. Which of the following is a unique property of this anesthetic agent?

answers.option: Low incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting
High dose required to induce sedation

question: A study was conducted in a village and the researcher wanted to see differences in fasting blood sugar among three groups of people. To do this he used a t-test instead of ANOVA. What statistical error may come as a result?
Which of the following statements is correct regarding the arterial supply of the spinal cord?

answers.option: Spinal arteries are branches of basilar artery
Entire cord supplied by artery of Adamkiewic
Anterior spinal artery primarily supplies anterior 2/3rd
Anterior spinal artery primarily supplies anterior 1/3rd

question: A 6-year-old male child weighing 20 kgs is brought to emergency with a history of weakness in both lower extremities, which has now progressively involved the trunk and upper limbs over a period of ten days. On examination, the sensations are intact, the tone is reduced, and reflexes are not elicited in lower limbs and +1 in upper limbs. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 59-year-old man diagnosed with Parkinson disease is initiated on bromocriptine therapy. Follow-up investigations that are performed six months later reveal bilateral hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound and elevation of serum creatinine. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of recurrent loss of consciousness followed by confusion. He had three similar episodes within the last 6 months. All these episodes are associated with the inability to recall the events that occurred during the episode. Trauma to the tongue and incontinence is observed by his family after each episode. Which of the following is the best procedure to reach an accurate diagnosis?

A second-year neurology resident is examining a patient diagnosed as a case of medial medullary syndrome. She detects hemiparesis, an impaired sensation of position and movements, and tactile discrimination (proprioception) all on the contralateral half of the body. Impaired sensations are due to lesions affecting which of the following structures?

A child requires multiple minor surgical procedures in the nasopharynx. Which drug has high surface local anesthetic activity and intrinsic vasoconstrictor actions that reduce bleeding in the mucous membrane?

A 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension presents to his primary care provider with a diagnosis of brainstem stroke syndrome. Which of the following clinical findings is not associated with this condition?

A 65-year-old female is brought by her husband with a history of weakness and wasting of hand muscles associated with fasciculation and stiffness in both legs for the past nine months. Motor neuron disease is suspected and a resident is instructed to perform a detailed neurological examination. Which of the following clinical findings is not consistent with the provisional diagnosis?

answers.option: Diminished pin-prick sensation on sole of feet

question: A 60-year-old male with uncontrolled hypertension, active smoker, alcohol abuse presents to the emergency room. On examination, he is drowsy, able to follow commands, has right mild facial paresis, right upper and lower extremity pronator drift, and has moderate spatial hemineglect. If there is a suspicion of a middle cerebral artery lesion in a stroke patient which of the following is present?
Which of the following is a screening questionnaire for alcohol use disorder?

answers.option: Clinical institute withdrawal assessment of alcohol

question: Lorazepam can be safely used as a pre-anesthetic medication in a patient undergoing liver transplantation without the fear of excessive CNS depression. What is the reason for this?

answers.option: A selective anxiolytic devoid of CNS depressant actions
Actively secreted into the GI tract

question: A 45-year-old male comes to an emergency room, with complaints of progressive weakness associated with decreased muscle mass and pain. On examination, there is muscle wasting and hyporeflexia. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is consistent with aseptic meningitis. At what point can postpolio syndrome develop in a patient?

A 32-year-old firefighter is brought to the emergency department because of burns on over 60% of their body. Immediate excision and grafting are planned. During the procedure, the patient develops malignant hyperthermia. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the findings in this patient?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of fever, headache, confusion, left eye drooping, and right-sided weakness for 4 days. He had a mild upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago. On examination, he has left eye ptosis with restricted medial gaze, 3/5 power on the right upper and lower extremity with brisk reflexes, and an upgoing plantar. Signs of meningeal irritation were absent. An MRI of the brain shows multiple large confluent areas of hyperintensities in the bilateral subcortical region, midbrain, and cerebellum with patchy enhancement. His cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed lymphocytic pleocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

For a 65-year-old patient with controlled diabetes mellitus and hypertension, about to undergo biopsy for a small lesion on the left cheek. Which is the definitive method of securing airway under general anesthesia?
A researcher wants to forecast the events of drug-related effects in cardiovascular patients. Which of the following is best suited in this scenario?

A newborn baby boy was taken to a pediatrician because the mother noticed his head was larger than normal. After a thorough examination and investigation, a diagnosis of gross dilation of the third and lateral ventricle was made. This was due to compression of the narrow ventricular channel in the midbrain. What is the compressed narrow channel called?
Intervertebral discs are composed of which of the following?

A 50-year-old smoker presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of difficulty in rising above from the ground and holding heavy objects in her hands for 3-4 weeks. She has lost significant weight in the past few months. Upon examination, she had a low-grade fever, but the rest of the physical examination was normal. She had decreased power in hip and shoulder girdle muscles with normal reflexes and sensations. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels are raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?

You receive a letter from the provincial health minister to design a course related to substance-related disorders for general practitioners. The letter mentions the rising trend of substance abuse in the general population and the intent of the government to tackle the issue by integrating the care of patients with substance use disorder in primary health care. Given the dearth of specialists, the idea sounds promising. When designing the training program which areas would be kept in mind?

answers.option: Types of drugs and their different effects

question: An ultrasound examination of a pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation confirms a diagnosis of a dilated fourth ventricle in the fetal brain. The appropriate part of the medulla oblongata that forms the floor of the dilated ventricle is which structure?

A medico-legal officer while exploring the posterior cranial fossa during autopsy noticed the cranial nerves IX, X, and cranial part of XI nerve emerging from a groove on the brainstem. This groove is present between which of the following?
Which spinal ligament connects two laminae and fuses with the facet joint?

At a family gathering, a 19-year-old male is observed talking and laughing excessively and speaking about working on an invention that will change the world. His brother tells you his behavior has changed over the past 3 weeks; he hardly sleeps, listens to songs all night long, and gets violent at times. He was previously a shy person who seldom met anyone and has never behaved this way before. What is the most likely condition he is suffering from?

A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting and headache for the past hour. He had a road traffic accident this morning. Glasgow's consciousness score is E4M6V4. Pupils are anisocoric and reactive. CT scan reveals a biconvex hyperdensity over the right temporoparietal region along with a fracture of the temporal bone. What is the most likely source of the blood?

A second-year resident in neurology while discussing diagrams of the brainstem notices a pair of rounded structures (eminences) on the posterior surface of the midbrain that forms a part of the auditory pathway. What are these structures?
A physician want to see the differences of blood sugar levels among three groups at different diabetic hospitals. What is the most suitable statistical test for accurate results in this case?
A 23-year-old female presents complaining of hearing changes and balance issues. Which cranial nerve is most likely involved in this case?

A 15-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with a complaint of fever, drowsiness, and fits for six hours. He had a cough, sore throat, and generalized muscle, and joint pain for the past three days. On examination, he is drowsy, with neck rigidity, and a positive Kernig's sign. He is also noticed to have a widespread petechial rash on his body. Which of the following is an indicator for a bad prognosis in this condition?

In patients with Parkinson disease, histologic studies suggest an imbalance in brain neurotransmitters. In contrast to normal individuals, patients with Parkinson disease have an abundance of which of the following neurons and associated neurotransmitters?

A 47-year-old man with seizure disorder presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. Because of a recent exacerbation in his seizures, he has been prescribed lamotrigine. What is the most likely mechanism of action of this medication?

answers.option: Binds to collapsing response mediator protein-2
Blockade of both sodium and calcium channels

question: A 45-year-old lady who has had a history of regular alcohol intake for the last five years starts hearing voices. The voices discuss the intention to kill her. She also sees the faces of deceased relatives. On inquiry, she also reports disturbed sleep and low mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male patient, previously diagnosed patient of diabetes mellitus type-2 and hypertension, is diagnosed with idiopathic Parkinson disease. Which of the following symptoms is not typically seen in this condition?

A 40-year-old married man presents to the emergency room with coarse tremors and visual hallucinations. He is unable to identify his family members. When asked about the time of the day he gives an incorrect answer. He also gives vague answers on the hospital whereabouts. Detailed history reveals regular and heavy alcohol intake for the last 10 years. On examination his pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg and respiratory rate of 32 per min. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident with an altered level of consciousness and vomiting. The patient has abnormal flexion on pain, opens eyes on pain with no verbal response. Pupils are equal and reactive to pain stimuli. CT scan reveals a crescent hyper-density over the right frontoparietal region along with the midline shift. What is the GCS of this patient?

Mitochondrial dysfunction has been implicated as a contributing factor for Parkinson disease, that is caused by mutations in genes that encode the proteins DJ-1, PINK1, and parkin. What is the mode of inheritance?

answers.option: Autosomal dominant and X- linked recessive

question: The use of cocaine produces its euphoric effect through following pharmacological action on the brain?

answers.option: Act as a direct agonist at alpha-2 noradrenergic receptors
Act as a direct agonist at dopaminergic D-2 receptors

question: A 19-year-old male is brought by his father to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of singing out loud throughout the night, sleeplessness, and claiming he is a famous singer. He had one similar episode in the past and one previous episode with symptoms of low energy and mood, for which he received treatment and reached a pre-morbid level of functionality. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male, with a history of hypertension and diabetes, is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset left-sided weakness for the last 1 hour. On examination, his blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg, his pulse is regular at 90 beats/min, and his GCS is 12/15. He has left-sided hemiparesis with upgoing plantars. CT scan of the brain reveals no findings. All baseline investigations are also within normal limits. What should be the first step in the management of this case?

A 29-year-old woman, 28 weeks pregnant, presents to the emergency room with persistent vomiting associated with mild to moderate diffuse headache and visual blurring for the last 2-3 weeks. Her last two pregnancies were uneventful. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg with a pulse of 102 beats/min and she is afebrile. The only significant finding on a neurologic exam is significant bilateral papilledema. Routine investigations show mild leukocytosis and sodium levels of 128 mEq/l. CSF analysis is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain is unremarkable, but MR venography showed filling defects in superior sagittal and bilateral transverse venous sinuses. APLA and the rest of the investigations for the autoimmune disease were negative. What could be the most likely predisposing etiological factor in her problem in this clinical vignette?

A 35-year-old man has sustained multiple injuries in a road traffic accident and has to undergo emergency surgery for penetrating abdominal injury. The patient is given rapid sequence general anesthesia. Which neuromuscular blocking agent is given for rapid sequence induction?
A researcher wants to know the relationship between the dose of salt consumption and its effect on blood pressure. Which test is most applicable in this scenario?

A 78-year-old man with generalized anxiety disorder and mild dementia visits his primary care physician. Physical examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen are unremarkable. Which of the following would be the best treatment option for his generalized anxiety disorder?

A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother who complains that he is inattentive in class and seems to go blank and stare into space at times. The neurological examination is unremarkable. What would be the most likely finding on EEG?
Which of the following anesthetics allows patients to ambulate faster and has the lowest risk of postoperative vomiting?
A researcher wants to see the mean difference of height amongst two groups of school children. What statistical test is best suited?

A medicolegal officer, while performing an autopsy, notices a cranial nerve concerned with accommodation and light reflex emerges from a groove on the medial side of the crus cerebri and passes forward in the cavernous sinus. What is the cranial nerve in question?
A medical researcher wants to predict the dose-related effects of a drug on cancer patients. What best predictive model will be helpful in the given scenario?

A neurophysician while discussing the MRI of a transverse section of the medulla oblongata at the level of decussation of lemnisci notices a cranial nerve emerge between olive and pyramid. What is the emerging nerve noticed by the neurophysician?

A 30-year-old man whose right lower limb was weakened at age of 9 years after a febrile illness, could walk with a small limp but otherwise well till 6 months back, started feeling stiffness and cramps in his affected limb. The stiffness and cramps are associated with twitching. This gradually became worse and he now requires support in order to walk. On examination, the bulk is markedly reduced in the right lower limb as compared to the left side, with visible fasciculation, areflexia but intact sensations. What is the most likely diagnosis?

The United Nations Office of Drug Control (UNODC) is an international body that has the charter to support the government in its effort to curb the problems related to drugs. According to the UNODC report, which drug is most commonly abused in Pakistan?

A 30-year-old male with a history of road traffic accident complains of severe backache and severe pain in both legs with paraparesis, urinary and fecal incontinence. A lesion of conus medullaris is suspected. Where does it terminate in adults?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after several episodes of epigastric discomfort followed by loss of sensorium. According to the attendants, he appears to be conscious but is non-responsive to his surroundings. During these 2-3 minute episodes he continues to make chewing movements and look around aimlessly. He reports a mild headache after the episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient suffers damage to the orbit in a road traffic incident resulting in damage to the third cranial nerve. Which of the following signs will be present?

answers.option: Pupillary dilatation and a torsional strabismus
Pupillary constriction and a lateral strabismus
Pupillary dilatation and a medial strabismus
Pupillary dilatation and a lateral strabismus
Pupillary constriction and a medial strabismus

question: What is the embryological mechanism of myelomeningocele?

answers.option: Reopening of anterior neuropore due to distension of central canal with CSF
Failure of closure of anterior neuropore
Failure of closure of posterior neuropore

question: The vertebral artery arises from which of the following structures?

Vascular disorders of medulla oblongata present with signs and symptoms due to damage IXth, Xth, and XIth cranial nerve nuclei. Damaged nuclei are seen in the section of the medulla oblongata at the same level at which structure?

A 21-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident. On examination, there is complete motor paralysis and loss of temperature, and pain perception distal to the lesion. He is diagnosed with spinal cord injury. The anterior cord syndrome occurs due to which of the following?

A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe right-sided headache for the last 6 hours associated with vomiting and increased sensitivity to light and sounds. Vital signs were stable. What would be the best to differentiate between the sinister and benign causes of headaches?

An elderly woman is about to undergo cardiothoracic surgery. If total intravenous anesthesia with fentanyl has been selected, then which of the following properties regarding fentanyl is the most appropriate one?

A 45-year-old woman on antiepileptic therapy complains of acne and increased facial hair growth. She is on no other medication. Which of the following most probable antiepileptic medication is responsible for the adverse effects this woman is experiencing?

A 28-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 9-year history of recurrent episodic headaches, lasting 30 minutes, at a frequency of 2-4 times a day. He claims that daily headache attacks lasted 3-4 weeks each year at the onset of winters but this year the attacks appeared at beginning of summer. The pain is excruciating and focused around his right eye. The right eye reddens, eyelid droops with ipsilateral clear nasal discharge. Physical examination, lumbar puncture, brain MRI (including pituitary views), and pituitary function blood tests are normal. What is the cause of this headache?

A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with abnormal movements of high frequency 10-12 Hertz involving his head and both the arms, bothering him mostly while taking meals and drinking water. His grandfather also had the same problem. What are these abnormal movements classified as?
Examination of a patient indicates that he has a medially directed strabismus (squint). This could be due to damage of what structure?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a history of progressive difficulty in walking for 6 months along with numbness in hands and feet. On examination, she has a bilateral high stepping gait with a positive Romberg sign. There was wasting and weakness of distal muscles of both upper and lower limbs with reduced reflexes. What will be the first investigation of choice to diagnose the disease?
Which of the following drugs blocks opiate receptors?

A 45-year-old lady is having severe toothache and is advised extraction. The lady wants it to be done under general anesthesia. She has a history of diabetes mellitus and taking oral hypoglycemic agents and her latest HbA1C is 4.7%. She also has a history of hypertension and takes antihypertensive medication. Her last blood pressure recorded was 135/85 mm Hg. All her routine lab investigations are within normal limits. According to ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists), she will be in what ASA classification?

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency room with recurring seizures for 3 hours. He has been running a fever for 2 days while exhibiting irritable behavior. Currently, he is very agitated and needs to be physically restrained. His body temperature is 104°F. Signs of meningeal irritation are absent. Plain CT scan brain shows abnormal hypo-dense signals in both temporal lobes. What is an important consideration in the management of this patient?

answers.option: Intravenous ceftriaxone is the drug of choice
Regular use of antipyretics may lead to early recovery
Lumbar puncture is contraindicated because of abnormal findings in CT brain
Early control of seizures is mandatory for good outcome
MRI brain is required as next step to confirm the diagnosis

question: An 81-year-old female comes to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of diminished facial expression (often termed masked facies), stooped posture, slowing of voluntary movement, taking progressively shortened, accelerated steps, rigidity, and a “pill-rolling” tremor. The first gene to be identified as a cause of Parkinson's Disease encodes a-synuclein, an abundant lipid-binding protein normally associated with synapses. Mutations in alpha-synuclein take the form of point mutations and amplification of the region of chromosome 4q21 that contains the gene. What is the mode of inheritance of these genes?

A 20-year-young man is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state with a history of head injury. His pupils are asymmetrically pinpoint, body temp 105 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of these hemorrhages occurred in this patient?

During a professional car race, a car moving at speed suddenly loses control and crashes into the guard grill. The driver sustained severe injuries to the face and neck. As a complication of these injuries, the driver develops paralysis of all four limbs. What is the most likely cause of paralysis?
